comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Not sure if that is 281 George Street,  Tyrrells Bookshop ?  See note and persistent URL.

Photo date 1891 (GPO clock) - 1896 (GPO additions).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Nicely found. Tyrrell's was there from the mid 1930s.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I see from Tyrrell's biography that the bookshop moved several times around Sydney. 1935 - ? at 281 George Street. I wonder when Tyrrell acquired Kerry's glass negatives.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Henry King's (the photographer) sign at 316 George Street (see note) can be seen in this earlier photo (see lack of Wiesener/Palings building) 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/4903239347/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] My first thought was either not long after 1917 when Kerry & Co. wound up, or shortly after 1928 when Kerry died. I found the answer on the Tyrrell Collection set description [I can hear you slapping your head from here!]: "The collection – an important record of city and country life - was bought by James R. Tyrrell in 1929".

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] D'oh!  I was looking in vain on the PhM site.  It means that this glass negative began life in the camera on the right hand side of the street;  lived at King's studio on the left hand side of the street, and finished up at the PhM via the right hand side of George Street.  Zig zag!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Adolphe Gabriel & Co, dentists, moved to cnr of George and Hunter Sts in ca. June 1888 (notice column 4) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13689419 ; they moved to 69 Hunter St in ca. March 1892 (notice towards bottom of column 3) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13860470 ; note though that they appear to have briefly upped stumps in September 1888 (see Hazlewood's notice towards bottom of column 5) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13697344 Per various digitised newspaper hits, I.R. Willows, chemist, occupied this George & Hunter Sts location during the later 1880s thru to at least 1895. T.F. Wiesener, was an 1880s-1890s Sydney watchmaker, jeweller, scientific instrument maker, etc. He had a shop at 334 George St during part of this time (see advert column 2) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71025090 The GPO clock faces were fitted between ca. July-August 1891 (see my notes at www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2554622065/ ) I'd say the date range is July/August 1891 (GPO clock faces fitted) - ca. March 1892 (Adolphe Gabriel moved to 69 Hunter St)
